string.text: Who are you?
I'm with the military, callsign "Peregrine". We've got troops stationed here to help out with maintaining the equipment. I'm also a part-time technician - if something breaks, I can repair it.
What's the current situation?

To be honest with you, it's shit. I don't have the tools I need, all thanks to the outstanding supply of the higher-ups. The equipment the Ecologists have got here isn't really making it easy for us, and it's gonna need some higher quality modifications... Managed to get the old receiver here repaired, though it's still spouting a bunch of gibberish. Our guys kicked the bucket at the Army Warehouses a couple of years ago, and it's still transmitting their voices.
Well, this is the Zone, you never know what'll happen. Anyway, best wishes.
Who are you?

The local cook, I guess. I can't even make something simple like an omelette, but somehow that's the assigned role I received in the army. I'm not a real soldier, so they put me here in Yantar. Anyway, they call me Spirit. Usually I take to drinking - it's so depressing around here. And you know... this is the main base of the Ecologists. My officers come here for inspections from time to time, and they don't like me drinking. Last time they were here, they poured my vodka out right before my eyes, bastards.
Go on.

Well, I know that getting ammo around here is rough, especially when Sakharov doesn't even sell any. I can hook you up with some stuff, but only Soviet-era shit, unfortunately. I've also got a few outfits, everything I've managed to steal is mine. 
What do you say? I can offer you four 9x18 mags or two mags of 5.45 for five bottles, and four mags for ten bottles. 
For ten bottles, I can share one mag of 7.62mm 7N1, or three boxes of 12x70 shot rounds, your choice. 
For fifteen bottles AND 7000 RU, you get three mages of 7.62x54 mm PP rounds. They are quite expensive you know... 
And for twenty bottles, I'll fetch you an entire Berill suit from the bins. Don't think I'm a scoundrel... it's not that bad, the lion's share goes to the guys. They've left me their equipment in a stash. I'll leave any goods between the hangars outside the bunker. I buy retail.
I'll consider it. Thank you.
I've brought some vodka.
That's great! Is there anything particular you want?
Six 9x18 mags.
Three 5.45 mags.
Six 5.45 mags.
Some buckshot ammo.
Two mags of 7.62 7N1.
Three boxes for the PKP.
The Berill.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
I've signalled to my guys - take it.
Remind me, what do you have?

This is what I've got: four mags of 9x18 for five bottles, two 5.45x39 mags for five bottles, four 5.45x39 mags for ten bottles, three packs of 12x70 for ten bottles, one mag of 7.62x54 7N1 for ten bottles, three box mags for the PKP for fifteen bottles and seven thousand rubles, and a Berill suit for twenty bottles.
Greetings, stalker.
Ah, stalker, what do you need?
I still have more data to collect. Let's go find some more mutants.
Greetings, stalker.
Stalker, you saved us! Our bunker would have met certain doom if you didn't step in to help. To show my gratitude, come to me for a free upgrade to your psi-helmet!
Hello, stalker. What brings you here?
What can you tell me about the Brain Scorcher?

Hmm, well... The field researchers only skirt the edge of the facility, so the little we know is mostly hearsay; second hand. What we do know is its effects. It seems to invade the mind of any who journey too close. The symptoms include migraines, hallucinations, tunnel vision, and without sounding unprofessional, zombification. If I had to give a scientific estimation, I'd call it a remote psi-transmitter, though I'd have to conduct more invasive research before settling on that conclusion.
Professor, I need a psi-protection helmet. My task requires me to move through the Brain Scorcher area, and without it, I won't be able to complete it.

I assume you understand the risk of going through these psychically volatile areas, do you?... Oh, alright, I believe you do. You wouldn't ask me about it otherwise. Well, there has been this one model we've been working on carefully, but it remains unfinished, and it lacks final calibrations. We can give you the psi-helmet right now as it is for a humble sum of 10,000 RU, but then you'd have to deal with the risk of using untested hardware! There's one more possibility, though: we can speed up the calibration progress, but that would require us to use more funds, and for you to wait. It would cost you about 17,500 RU. If you are willing to part with such a sum, we'll begin utilizing it immediately to finish our calibrations, which should take approximately two days, give or take.

I assume you understand the risk of going through these psychically volatile areas, do you?... Oh, alright, I believe you do. You wouldn't ask me about it otherwise. Well, there has been this one model we've been working on carefully, but it remains unfinished, and it lacks final calibrations.
I'm in a hurry. I'll take the prototype.

If you insist. I am quite certain that your job requires your equipment to be in perfect operational condition... Oh, I nearly forgot: you can always take it back to us for a final calibration. If you feel something is wrong, head straight to us. We can't afford any losses. So, this will cost you 10,000 RU.
Here's the money. Thank you, professor.
Not at all. But I would like you to test it first. You can help us by disabling the psi-emitter in the laboratory just north of here. Let's hope it will guard your consciousness well...
I've decided to let you finish your work. Please calibrate this helmet thoroughly.

You don't know what relief this brings to me and my colleagues. Letting us finish the final calibrations will greatly minimize the risk of injury, and we really wouldn't want to feel guilty of supplying you with untested gear... So, since you've already provided financial aid to our cause, a final calibration should cost you about 8,000 RU, and you'll need to wait approximately two days.
I hope my patience will be worth the fully calibrated version.

Indeed it will be. Once we finish working on this helmet, you'll be able to wander around the Zone freely, without suffering the risk of any psi-damage, as its psi-protective potential will be maximized. So... it will be 17,500 RU.

Indeed it will be. Once we finish working on this helmet, you'll be able to wander around the Zone freely, without suffering the risk of any psi-damage, as its psi-protective potential will be maximized. Since you've helped us out, I may part with the device free of charge.
Alright, I'll wait for the fully calibrated psi-helmet. Work your magic.
Thank you, stalker. I shall commence final calibrations now. Come and visit me in a couple days.
Is it ready yet?
It is! Here you go. But I would like you to test it first. You can help us by disabling the psi-emitter in the laboratory just north of here. Let's hope it will guard your consciousness well...
Not yet. Please come back later.
I need to think about it.
Very well. Don't worry; we'll keep the psi-helmet for later.
Anything interesting happening in the scientific community lately?
Our research into the Night Star artifact has helped advance protective armour. We may see some spectacular results in a few years.
There is an old hypothesis that Snorks are the next stage of human evolution. Even after procuring tissue samples, the topic is hotly debated.
We recently conducted some fascinating experiments on Bloodsuckers that...on second thought, it's probably better you don't know.

As an intellectual, you might appreciate this - our research has discovered that the so called "eye" of the Flesh is also equipped with...olfactory receptors! Not only can they see out their eyes, but also smell out of them! Isn't that fascinating?
Have you seen the latest batch of mutant samples that were brought in? We've been transplanting as many as we can onto...voluntary assistants. We may be on the verge of starting a craze!
We've done it! We've finally managed to create the rare Pellicle artifact under laboratory conditions! It is a breakthrough truly worthy of a Nobel Prize!
Some of our colleages have taken to eating cooked mutant meat as a way to test the effect of mutated protein on the human body. I don't know why they don't simply pay the 100 Rads a visit instead.
The Urchin artifact has allowed us to make potent anti-radiation medication. Chances are you may have benefitted from our research several times already.
Progress has been slow lately. All the mutant sounds outside make it difficult to concentrate.
We're trying to prove that Vortex anomalies are not merely gravitational, but rather spatial and temporal in nature. If so, their artifacts could hold the key to teleportation technologies.
Moonlight artifacts could well be the solution to the looming global energy crisis. Electro anomalies are a keen point of interest for us.
No, nothing especially interesting right now.
You're in the wrong place, buddy... and you better leave before we make it the wrong time, too.
You looking for trouble or something? Get out of here before you find it!
Get lost, buddy. Do that, and we'll keep it peaceful.
